title: TGF1+CCR5+ neutrophil subset increases in bone marrow and causes age-related osteoporosis in male mice - Nature Communications
author: Li; Jinbo; Yao; Zhenqiang; Xin; Duan; Rong; Yi; Xiangjiao; Ayoub; Akram; Sanders; James O; Mesfin; Addisu; Boyce; Brendan F
description: Age-related osteoporosis is known to be dependent on TGF1 signalling. Here the authors show that a subset of neutrophils (identified by TGF1+CCR5+) increase during aging in mouse bone marrow resulting in bone loss, while a CCR5 antagonist can reduce the neutrophil numbers and increase bone mass in aged mice.
cleaned_text: Abstract TGF1 induces age-related bone loss by promoting degradation of TNF receptor-associated factor 3 (TRAF3), levels of which decrease in murine and human bone during aging. We report that a subset of neutrophils (TGF1+CCR5+) is the major source of TGF1 in murine bone. Their numbers are increased in bone marrow (BM) of aged wild-type mice and adult mice with TRAF3 conditionally deleted in mesenchymal progenitor cells (MPCs), associated with increased expression in BM of the chemokine, CCL5, suggesting that TRAF3 in MPCs limits TGF1+CCR5+ neutrophil in BM of young mice. During aging, TGF1-induced TRAF3 degradation in MPCs promotes NF-B-mediated expression of CCL5 MPCs, associated with higher TGF1+CCR5+ neutrophil numbers in BM where they induce bone loss. TGF1+CCR5+ neutrophils decreased bone mass in male mice. The antagonist, maraviroc, reduced TGF1+CCR5+ neutrophil numbers in BM and increased bone mass in aged mice. 15-mon-old mice with TGFRII specifically deleted in MPCs had lower numbers of TGF1+CCR5+ neutrophils in BM and higher bone volume than wild-type littermates. We propose that pharmacologic reduction of TGF1+CCR5+ neutrophil numbers in BM could treat or prevent age-related osteoporosis. Introduction Low-level chronic inflammation occurring in the absence of overt infection during aging, termed inflammaging [1](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR1), is common and implicated in the osteoporosis [6](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR6). Osteoporosis, the most common bone disease in aging humans, is characterized by decreased bone mass and strength due to increased osteoclastic bone resorption and decreased osteoblastic bone formation, leading to increased fracture risk, morbidity and mortality [7](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR7). Treatment includes anti-resorptive and anabolic drugs [8](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR8), [9](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR9); the former have side effects that now limit patients' willingness to take them [10](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR10), and the latter can be given for only 2 years to patients with severe osteoporosis [11](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR11), [12](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR12), after which bone loss accelerates [13](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR13). Thus, there a growing need to develop new treatments, based on better understanding of the molecular mechanisms causing bone loss. We reported that during aging: RANKL, an essential osteoclastogenic cytokine by receptor-associated factor 3 (TRAF3) and thus activating NF-B signaling in osteoclast precursors to enhance osteoclastogenesis [15](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR15); and TGF1, a cytokine released from bone during resorption [16](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR16), inhibits bone formation [16](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR16) by activating NF-B, a master regulator of inflammatory responses [17](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR17) and bone remodeling [18](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR18), in mesenchymal progenitor cells (MPCs). Both cytokines mediate signaling in cells through TRAFs, which can positively and negatively regulate signaling [19](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR19), [20](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR20). TRAF3 typically inhibits NF-B restricts TGF1-induced inhibition of osteoblast MPCs by inhibiting GSK-3-mediated degradation of -catenin [16](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR16), expression of which is essential for bone formation [22](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR22). TRAF3 protein levels are reduced in bone from aged humans and mice, associated with increased levels of active TGF1 in BM [16](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR16). Mice with TRAF3 conditional knockout (cKO) in osteoclast precursors develop early onset osteoporosis because of excessive bone resorption [15](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR15), while mice with TRAF3 cKO in MPCs develop osteoporosis due to reduced bone formation and increased resorption [16](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR16). By degrading TRAF3 in MPCs, TGF1 promotes increased resorption and decreased bone formation [15](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR15), [16](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR16), implicating it in the pathogenesis of low-level chronic inflammation-related osteoporosis. However, there are small numbers of MPCs in bone marrow (BM) of normal mice, and bone resorption decreases in mice and humans during aging [23](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR23), resulting in less TGF1 being released from bone in aged mice, suggesting that there is another more common source(s) of TGF1 in BM causing osteoporosis. Inflammaging is accompanied by alterations in immune cells, in the microenvironment in lymphoid/non-lymphoid tissues, and in chemokines and cytokines that mediate interactions between immune cells and the microenvironment [24](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR24). However, it remains largely unknown if age-related alterations of immune cells in BM cause bone loss during aging. Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) continuously regenerate immune and blood cells and expand numerically in BM during aging, when they commit preferentially to myeloid over lymphoid differentiation [25](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR25), leading to impaired adaptive immune responses and increased susceptibility to systemic infection [26](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR26). Leukocytes are the most abundant cell type in BM and are heterogenous. As the most abundant sub-population of leukocytes, neutrophils express TGF1 in tumor cells [27](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR27), normal intestinal cells [28](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR28), and in respiratory cells in asthmatic subjects [29](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR29), but whether TGF1-expressing neutrophils or other immune cells are involved in inflammaging and age-related osteoporosis remains unclear. Despite these advances, the major sources of TGF1 in inflammaging-induced osteoporosis remain unknown. Here, we report that TGF1+CCR5+ neutrophils (which we call TCNs), an immune cell subset, are the major cellular source of TGF1 in BM. Their numbers are increased in BM of aged mice, associated with increased expression by MPCs of CCL5 because of TGF1-induced degradation of TRAF3 in MPCs. Injection of TCNs into male NGS mice significantly reduced bone mass. Aged mice given the FDA-approved CCR5 inhibitor, maraviroc, and mice lacking TGFRII in MPCs have reduced numbers of TCNs in BM and increased bone mass, supporting our posit that these neutrophils cause age-related bone loss. Discussion We have identified a subset of TGF/CCR5-expressing neutrophils (TCNs) that are increased in BM and decreased in blood, lymph nodes, and spleens of 18-22-mon-old WT mice. TCNs are also increased in 12-mon-old P-cKO mice, in which MPCs lack TRAF3 expression, associated with reduced bone mass. In contrast, 15-mon-old TRII-cKO mice, which lack TGF receptor II, have low numbers of TCNs in BM and high bone mass. Importantly, TCNs from aged male mice inhibited bone formation in vivo when they were injected into NSG mice or implanted into NSG mice along with MPCs from WT, but not from TRII-cKO mice, implicating TCNs as a cause of age-related bone loss through TGF. We propose that increased amounts of TGF1 released by TCNs during aging induce TRAF3 degradation in BM MPCs through TGF receptor II signaling, causing MPCs to increase their production of CCL5 through enhanced NF-B signaling; in turn, increased CCL5 levels in BM are associated with increased numbers of TCNs in BM, and thus more TGF1 is released in the BM microenvironment. We also propose that in young and adult male mice, TGF levels and TCN numbers are physiological, which allows TRAF3 in MPCs to restrict NF-B-mediated production of RANKL and CCL5 to levels that limit osteoclast formation and TCN numbers in BM, respectively. This holds bone resorption and formation at optimal levels to maintain skeletal integrity in young and adult mice. In contrast, TGF1 released by increased numbers of TCNs in BM during aging degrades TRAF3 in MPCs and transcription of Tnfsf11 (encodes RANKL) and Ccl5. As a result, TCN numbers increase in BM during aging and cause osteoporosis in male mice by stimulating RANKL-induced resorption and inhibiting bone formation in a self-amplifying feedback loop (Fig. [9](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#Fig9)). In support of this mechanism, total TGF1 protein levels are much higher in murine BM cells than in bone. We reported previously that levels of active TGF are higher in samples of BM from 19-mon- than from 3-mon-old WT mice and in samples of vertebral bone containing BM from aged humans than from children [16](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR16), suggesting that TGF released from BM cells gets activated by a mechanism different from the osteoclast-derived acid that activates TGF released from bone matrix in resorption lacunae [34](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR34). A limitation of our study is that we have not investigated how TGF from TCNs is activated in BM, but possibilities include MMP9 [35](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR35), which can be activated by TNF [36](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR36) (a of inflammaging [37](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR37)) and neutrophils Although TGF is released from resorbing bone [39](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR39), bone remodeling is lower in aged than in adult mice and humans [23](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR23), [40](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR40). We propose that higher TGF expression levels in BM cells than in bone and even higher expression levels during aging suggest a key role for BM cells in the regulation of bone remodeling. We found that monocytes (Ly6Chi6G-) also express TGF1. However, we focused here on TCNs because they are much more abundant in BM during aging (Fig. [2](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#Fig2)) and age-related osteoporosis is characterized by decreased bone formation, while bone-derived monocytes/macrophage have been reported to stimulate bone formation [41](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR41). Given the large numbers of TGF-expressing neutrophils in BM of aged mice, we believe that these are a much more important source of TGF for degradation of TRAF3 in MPCs than TGF released from resorbing bone. However, definitive proof of this will require additional studies. TGF1 is expressed by various cell types [42](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR42), and has been implicated in the pathogenesis of many fibrotic, inflammatory and neoplastic diseases [43](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR43) for which TGF inhibitors have been developed, with some success [44](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR44). For example, the TGF Ab, 1D11, increased bone mass and prevented breast cancer bone metastasis-induced osteolysis in mice [45](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR45). However, despite promising results [44](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR44), [46](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR46) and an ongoing phase 1 trial of 1D11 in osteogenesis imperfecta ( [https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03064074](https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03064074)), no TGF inhibitor has received FDA approval. Although Prx1 is expressed predominantly in appendicular bones in embryos [32](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR32), it is also expressed in vertebrae [16](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR16). Prx1 specifically tracks mesenchymal lineage cells, and mice with global knockout of Prx1 have defects in the skull, limbs, and vertebrae [16](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR16), [32](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR32), [47](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR47). The 15-mon-old TGFRII cKO mice we generated have markedly increased trabecular bone volume and cortical thickness in vertebrae and long bones, consistent with the expression pattern of Prx1. Increased bone mass has been reported in 2-mon-old mice with TGFRII cKO driven in osteoblasts by the osteocalcin promoter [48](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR48). Others have described defective limb formation in embryos of TGFRII cKO mice [49](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR49) and osteoarthritis in 12-mon-old mice [50](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR50). We did not observe these abnormalities in our cKO mice, which may reflect differences in genetic backgrounds. We found that maraviroc, an FDA-approved small molecule CCR5 antagonist [51](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR51), given for 4 wk to 22-mon-old male WT mice or for 10 d to 3-mon-old male NSG mice injected with aged TCNs had remarkable skeletal effects: it not only reduced TCN numbers in BM, but also increased bone mass, associated with increased bone formation and decreased resorption. Lee et al. reported that a CCR5 Ab inhibited the function, but not formation, of human osteoclasts, and that Ccr5 global knockout mice have dysfunctional osteoclasts [52](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR52). However, they also noted that the role of CCL5/CCR5 signaling in bone cells is controversial. The effects we observed with maraviroc could be different from those of an anti-human CCR5 Ab or from global deletion of CCR5, since maraviroc binds to a different site on CCR5 from the CCR5 Ab [53](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR53), and the range of its inhibitory effects is different from global CCR5 gene deletion. Lee et al. also reported that CCR5 mediates RANKL-induced bone resorption [52](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR52). Our signaling mediates accumulation of TCNs in BM resulting in enhanced bone resorption, inhibited bone formation, and bone loss during aging (Fig. [9](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#Fig9)) compatible with CCR5 KO mice being resistant to RANKL [52](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR52). CCR5 is involved in recruitment of neutrophils in murine models of ischemia-reperfusion injury [54](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR54), endotoxin-induced lung injury, and pneumonia [55](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR55), and neutrophils are a source of TGF in tumors [27](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR27), the intestine [28](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR28), and in asthmatic subjects [29](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR29). Here, we report CCR5+ neutrophils being a major cellular source of TGF in murine BM and important regulators of bone homeostasis, as evidenced by in vitro co-culture and in vivo ectopic implantation and adoptive transfer of this subset into NSG mice. We believe that these TCNs are distinct from other reported immune cell subpopulations involved in the pathogenesis of age-associated osteoporosis. We found that neutrophils have significantly higher CCR5 expression levels than monocytes (Figs. levels than TGF1-negative neutrophils (Suppl. Fig. [9](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#MOESM1)). Our findings are consistent with maraviroc acting by inhibiting TCN return to BM. Another limitation of our study is that we have not shown directly that CCL5/CCR5 signaling attracts increased numbers of TCNs to the BM during aging. This would require generating mice with CCR5 knocked out in Ly6G+ myeloid lineage cells, which is beyond the scope of this paper at this time. Maraviroc could also have worked by affecting the functions of other cells involved in suppression or promotion of bone remodeling. For example, although maraviroc binds to CCR5 to block interaction between HIV-1 and CCR5 and prevent HIV-1 entry into host T cells and macrophages [51](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR51), recent studies have shown that it also blocks interactions between cancer cells and immune and other cells in the tumor microenvironment [56](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR56), reprograms immunosuppressive myeloid cells, and enhances autocrine CCL5-CCR5 axis in BM [57](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR57). In addition, maraviroc is being studied in clinical trials in breast, colorectal, and pancreatic cancer and Kaposi's sarcoma [58](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR58) following studies revealing that CCL5 and/or CCR5 overexpressed in many cancers (including breast, gastrointestinal, prostatic, melanoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, and multiple myeloma), and they promote tumor growth, extracellular matrix remodeling, angiogenesis, immune and stromal cell recruitment, and immunosuppressive polarization of macrophages [58](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR58). Thus, it will be important to determine exactly how maraviroc increases bone mass in aged mice. Maraviroc, overall, is well tolerated by HIV-1 patients [59](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR59), but it can have serious adverse effects ( [https://www.fda.gov/media/116857/download](https://www.fda.gov/media/116857/download)). We did not detect obvious adverse effects in the mice treated with this drug for 4 wk. However, it will also be important to determine if it can be administered long-term to mice to prevent age-related bone loss, since occasional severe side effects that may be acceptable in patients with malignancies and HIV infections [60](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR60) will not be in patients with benign diseases, such as osteoporosis. Our findings suggest that maraviroc could be repurposed in this way to treat and prevent age-related osteoporosis in humans. Neutrophils are generally regarded as short-lived cells, generated in the BM, and released continuously into the circulation as inactive cells [61](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR61). They migrate to sites of infection in response to chemotactic signals where they become primed to destroy invading pathogens through enhanced cytotoxic capacity and lifespan, and ultimately undergo apoptosis [62](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR62). Unprimed neutrophils undergo senescence, and in response to chemokines, including CXCL12, return to the BM where they impair HSC mobilization [63](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR63) and undergo apoptosis [64](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR64). Cxcl12 gene transcription is higher in CD45- BMCs from adult P-cKO and old WT mice than from adult WT mice. Interestingly, recent studies have revealed that unprimed neutrophils en-route for elimination can be co-opted in tissues, such as lungs and intestines, where their lifespan can be extended, allowing them to adapt to local environments and develop non-canonical functions that tailor their properties to support organ homeostasis and repair mechanisms, including angiogenesis [65](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR65). Growing evidence points to neutrophils having a broader range of functions than traditionally has been attributed to them, including in cancer [66](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR66), stroke [67](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR67), auto-immune, and renal disease [68](/articles/s41467-023-35801-z#ref-CR68), raising the likelihood that novel functions for them will be identified in additional diseases. It will be important to determine if TCNs are co-opted by cells in the BM and if their lifespan is extended to enhance the deleterious effects that we have discovered they have on bone mass during aging. Statistics and reproducibility All results are given as the mean ± S.D. Variance was similar between groups for most parameters assessed. Comparisons between two groups were analyzed using Student's two-tailed unpaired t test and those among 3 or more groups using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey's post hoc multiple comparisons. p values <0.05 were considered statistically significant. Statistical data in this study were analyzed and dot plots were generated using GraphPad Prism 6. The sample size for in vivo experiments is based on an unpaired t-test power analysis carried out by our statistician using SigmaStat Statistical Software: 5-8 mice were needed in each group where bone parameters were being assessed to detect significant differences from controls with an alpha error of 5%. The power is 0.98, i.e., there is 98% chance of detecting a specific effect with 95% confidence when alpha = 0.05. No data were excluded from the analyses. All in vitro experiments were repeated twice independently with similar results. All in vivo experiments were carried out once.
